channel.title: High voltage caps?
channel.description: Would any of you know where I can get capacitors that have around the values of 10kV+ and around 100uf + IF you want to know I'm going to make a few high voltage projects... eg jacobs ladder and a coil gun (the need for the capacitors) I'll be using some ignition coils and possibably a flyback transformer from a crt... :D :D

/Facepalm

I need to store the voltage, I already know how I’m generating it…

item.title: High voltage caps?
item.dc:creator: @bootnecklad bootnecklad
item.description:
@bootnecklad wrote:

I’d like to stay away from the camera capacitors and have already had bad experience with them. Also getting hold of them is a problem. One of the many problems I have is creating a bank of them there quite big and bulky. To get enough of them for around 5kw plus is quite a few. Some of the biggest I’ve come across was a 200v capacitor and it was around 300uf so:

5000/200=25 and thats if the tolerance doesnt effect it =/ . A bank of 25 of those capacitors is way to bulky. Some of the ones I’ve been googling have only been around 400v but it’s so much easy to handle(less soldering joints to go wrong, less of them to fail and test if something goes wrong etc etc.) This is the one I’m thinking about nice and small high voltage and 470uf. I’m going to need a few of them but I might get a plug in board for them maybe. here

Read full topic

item.title: High voltage caps?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Why not just wire together a bunch of lower voltage capacitors to make a high voltage one? Remember you need to wire them in parallel and not in series. You can get fairly large capacitors from disposable cameras.

Read full topic
